title: 109_hr3558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Amendments Act of 2005". The Pick-Sloan Missouri River Basin program, authorized by the Flood Control Act of 1944, aimed to promote economic development in the US. The Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project, a key part of the program, impacted the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe by flooding their land and causing economic and cultural damage. Compensation has been provided to some Indian tribes. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe suffered economic and cultural damage from the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. Congress provided compensation through the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act, but it did not include additional compensation for tribal members who lost land. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act did not provide additional compensation for tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. This Act aims to allow the Cheyenne River Sioux Tribal Recovery Trust Fund to compensate those members and capitalize the fund. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act aims to provide additional compensation for tribal members who lost land due to the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to ensure fair compensation for tribal members who lost land in the Oahe Dam and Reservation project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to include member landowners who lost land in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe Equitable Compensation Act is amended to include land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project on the Cheyenne River Sioux Reservation. This includes funding from the power program for the Tribal Recovery Trust Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits 25% of the power program funds into the Fund annually, starting from October 1, 2004, until the total deposited equals a specified amount. This amount includes $290,722,958 and accrued interest. The Secretary of the Treasury deposits 25% of power program funds into the Fund annually, starting from October 1, 2004, until a specified amount is reached, including $290,722,958 and accrued interest determined by applying the Lehman Government Bond Index. The Secretary of the Treasury, in consultation with the Tribal Council, may provide additional compensation to member landowners for land acquisition in the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Secretary of the Interior shall provide records to the Tribe to assist in processing claims of heirs of member landowners for land acquired for the Oahe Dam and Reservoir Project. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe is eligible for certain programs and services under the Equitable Compensation Act. The Cheyenne River Sioux Tribe is eligible for certain programs and services under the Equitable Compensation Act, with amendments allowing member landowners to also request assistance.
